Alice thought she might as well go back, and see how the game was going on, as she heard the Queen’s voice in the distance, screaming with passion. She had already heard her sentence three of the players to be executed for having missed their turns, and she did not like the look of things at all, as the game was in such confusion that she never knew whether it was her turn or not. So she went in search of her hedgehog.

The hedgehog was engaged in a fight with another hedgehog, which seemed to Alice an excellent opportunity for croqueting one of them with the other: the only difficulty was, that her flamingo was gone across to the other side of the garden, where Alice could see it trying in a helpless sort of way to fly up into a tree. By the time she had caught the flamingo and brought it back, the fight was over, and both the hedgehogs were out of sight: ‘but it doesn’t matter much,’ thought Alice, ‘as all the arches are gone from this side of the ground.’ So she tucked it away under her arm, that it might not escape again, and went back for a little more conversation with her friend.

When she got back to the Cheshire Cat, she was surprised to find quite a large crowd collected round it: there was a dispute going on between the executioner, the King, and the Queen, who were all talking at once, while all the rest were quite silent, and looked very uncomfortable.

The moment Alice appeared, she was appealed to by all three to settle the question, and they repeated their arguments to her, though, as they all spoke at once, she found it very hard indeed to make out exactly what they said.

The executioner’s argument was, that you couldn’t cut off a head unless there was a body to cut it off from: that he had never had to do such a thing before, and he wasn’t going to begin at his time of life.

The King’s argument was, that anything that had a head could be beheaded, and that you weren’t to talk nonsense.

The Queen’s argument was, that if something wasn’t done about it in less than no time, she’d have everybody executed, all round. (It was this last remark that had made the whole party look so grave and anxious.)

Alice could think of nothing else to say but ‘It belongs to the Duchess: you’d better ask her about it.’

‘She’s in prison,’ the Queen said to the executioner: ‘fetch her here.’ And the executioner went off like an arrow.

The Cat’s head began fading away the moment he was gone, and, by the time he had come back with the Duchess, it had entirely disappeared; so the King and the executioner ran wildly up and down looking for it, while the rest of the party went back to the game.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
She had not gone far before she came upon a curious sight: all the players, the Queen included, were gathered in a sort of circle, leaving the middle of the croquet-ground quite empty. Alice slipped in quietly, and looked about her to see what could have happened. The moment she appeared, the Queen, who had been busily engaged in shouting at the top of her voice, caught sight of her and called out, “Where have you been?”

“I’ve been looking for a hedgehog,” said Alice meekly. “Did you happen to see one?”

The Queen gave a shrill laugh. “They’re all gone to the other end of the ground,” she said. “And just as I was getting on so nicely! I should have won, that’s certain, if it hadn’t been for the wretched creatures!”

Alice did not like to contradict the Queen, so she said nothing, and walked slowly off towards the other end of the ground. The other players had joined her by this time, and she found herself walking in a sort of procession, with the King and Queen at the front, and all the rest following behind. They had not gone far before they came upon the Gryphon, lying fast asleep in the sun. (If you don’t know what a Gryphon is, look at the picture.)

“Up, lazy thing!” said the Queen, “and take this young lady with you, to see the Mock Turtle, and to hear his history. I must go back and see after some executions I have ordered;” and she walked off, leaving Alice alone with the Gryphon. Alice did not quite like the look of the creature, but on the whole she thought it would be quite as safe to stay with it as to go after that savage Queen: so she waited.

The Gryphon sat up and rubbed its eyes: then it watched the Queen till she was out of sight: then it chuckled. “What fun!” said the Gryphon, half to itself, half to Alice.

“What is the fun?” said Alice.

“Why, she,” said the Gryphon. “It’s all her fancy, that: they never executes nobody, you know. Come on!”

“Everybody says ‘come on!’ here,” thought Alice, as she went slowly after it: “I never was so ordered about in all my life, never!”

They had not gone far before they saw the Mock Turtle in the distance, sitting sad and lonely on a little ledge of rock, and, as they came nearer, Alice could hear him sighing as if his heart would break. She pitied him deeply. “What is his sorrow?” she asked the Gryphon, and the Gryphon answered, very nearly in the same words as before, “It’s all his fancy, that: he hasn’t got no sorrow, you know. Come on!”

So they went up to the Mock Turtle, who looked at them with large eyes full of tears, but said nothing.

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER IX. The Mock Turtle’s Story

events.title: Alice and the Moralizing Duchess
detailed_summary: The Duchess expresses great happiness at seeing Alice again, linking arms with her companionably.
Alice reciprocates the pleasure, finding the Duchess in a surprisingly good mood and privately theorizing that pepper was the cause of her earlier ill temper in the kitchen.

Alice internally reflects on becoming a Duchess herself and banning pepper, leading her to develop a theory that various foods influence personality: pepper causes hot tempers, vinegar causes sourness, camomile causes bitterness, and sweets cause sweet tempers.
Lost in thought, Alice is startled when the Duchess points out her abstraction, promising to find the moral of it later.
Alice tentatively suggests that perhaps not everything possesses a moral.
The Duchess dismisses this, insisting on the universality of morals if one looks for them, and presses closer to Alice.
Alice feels uncomfortable with the Duchess's proximity due to her perceived ugliness and the awkwardness of the Duchess resting her sharp chin on Alice's shoulder, but endures it to avoid rudeness.
To maintain conversation, Alice remarks that the croquet game seems to be proceeding better.
The Duchess agrees, offering the moral that love makes the world go round.
Alice quietly shares a different saying: that the world turns because everyone minds their own business.
The Duchess considers this much the same, digs her chin into Alice's shoulder again, and provides another moral concerning the relationship between sense and sounds.
Alice silently observes the Duchess's persistent habit of finding morals everywhere.
The Duchess pauses, then explains she refrains from putting her arm around Alice's waist because she is unsure about the temperament of Alice's flamingo croquet mallet, asking if she should test it.
Alice cautiously discourages the experiment, warning that the flamingo might bite.
The Duchess agrees, noting that both flamingoes and mustard bite, and derives the moral 'Birds of a feather flock together'.
Alice logically points out that mustard is not a bird.
The Duchess compliments Alice's clarity and readily agrees.
Alice tentatively identifies mustard as a mineral.
The Duchess concurs enthusiastically, inventing a nearby mustard mine and offering a moral about ownership: 'The more there is of mine, the less there is of yours.'
Alice, not having paid attention to the last moral, corrects herself, stating mustard is a vegetable.
The Duchess agrees once more, giving the moral 'Be what you would seem to be', followed immediately by an extraordinarily long and confusing elaboration of the same principle.
Alice politely responds that she would grasp the lengthy moral better if it were written down, as she cannot follow it when spoken.
The Duchess replies with satisfaction that she could say much more if she desired.
Alice requests that the Duchess not exert herself further.
The Duchess waves off the idea of trouble, declaring she gifts Alice everything she has said so far.
Alice privately thinks this is a worthless gift and is glad birthday presents aren't similar, but keeps the thought to herself.
The Duchess jabs Alice with her chin again, asking if she is thinking once more.
Alice sharply affirms her right to think, feeling increasingly bothered.
The Duchess retorts that Alice's right to think is comparable to pigs' right to fly and begins to state the moral...

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “You can’t think how glad I am to see you again, you dear old thing!” said the Duchess, as she tucked her arm affectionately into Alice’s, and they walked off together.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Just about as much right,” said the Duchess, “as pigs have to fly; and the m—”

events.text_segment:
“You can’t think how glad I am to see you again, you dear old thing!” said the Duchess, as she tucked her arm affectionately into Alice’s, and they walked off together.
Alice was very glad to find her in such a pleasant temper, and thought to herself that perhaps it was only the pepper that had made her so savage when they met in the kitchen.
“When I’m a Duchess,” she said to herself, (not in a very hopeful tone though), “I won’t have any pepper in my kitchen at all. Soup does very well without—Maybe it’s always pepper that makes people hot-tempered,” she went on, very much pleased at having found out a new kind of rule, “and vinegar that makes them sour—and camomile that makes them bitter—and—and barley-sugar and such things that make children sweet-tempered. I only wish people knew that: then they wouldn’t be so stingy about it, you know—”
She had quite forgotten the Duchess by this time, and was a little startled when she heard her voice close to her ear. “You’re thinking about something, my dear, and that makes you forget to talk. I can’t tell you just now what the moral of that is, but I shall remember it in a bit.”
“Perhaps it hasn’t one,” Alice ventured to remark.
“Tut, tut, child!” said the Duchess. “Everything’s got a moral, if only you can find it.” And she squeezed herself up closer to Alice’s side as she spoke.
Alice did not much like keeping so close to her: first, because the Duchess was very ugly; and secondly, because she was exactly the right height to rest her chin upon Alice’s shoulder, and it was an uncomfortably sharp chin. However, she did not like to be rude, so she bore it as well as she could.
“The game’s going on rather better now,” she said, by way of keeping up the conversation a little.
“’Tis so,” said the Duchess: “and the moral of that is—‘Oh, ’tis love, ’tis love, that makes the world go round!’”
“Somebody said,” Alice whispered, “that it’s done by everybody minding their own business!”
“Ah, well! It means much the same thing,” said the Duchess, digging her sharp little chin into Alice’s shoulder as she added, “and the moral of that is—‘Take care of the sense, and the sounds will take care of themselves.’”
“How fond she is of finding morals in things!” Alice thought to herself.
“I dare say you’re wondering why I don’t put my arm round your waist,” the Duchess said after a pause: “the reason is, that I’m doubtful about the temper of your flamingo. Shall I try the experiment?”
“He might bite,” Alice cautiously replied, not feeling at all anxious to have the experiment tried.
“Very true,” said the Duchess: “flamingoes and mustard both bite. And the moral of that is—‘Birds of a feather flock together.’”
“Only mustard isn’t a bird,” Alice remarked.
“Right, as usual,” said the Duchess: “what a clear way you have of putting things!”
“It’s a mineral, I think,” said Alice.
“Of course it is,” said the Duchess, who seemed ready to agree to everything that Alice said; “there’s a large mustard-mine near here. And the moral of that is—‘The more there is of mine, the less there is of yours.’”
“Oh, I know!” exclaimed Alice, who had not attended to this last remark, “it’s a vegetable. It doesn’t look like one, but it is.”
“I quite agree with you,” said the Duchess; “and the moral of that is—‘Be what you would seem to be’—or if you’d like it put more simply—‘Never imagine yourself not to be otherwise than what it might appear to others that what you were or might have been was not otherwise than what you had been would have appeared to them to be otherwise.’”
“I think I should understand that better,” Alice said very politely, “if I had it written down: but I can’t quite follow it as you say it.”
“That’s nothing to what I could say if I chose,” the Duchess replied, in a pleased tone.
“Pray don’t trouble yourself to say it any longer than that,” said Alice.
“Oh, don’t talk about trouble!” said the Duchess. “I make you a present of everything I’ve said as yet.”
“A cheap sort of present!” thought Alice. “I’m glad they don’t give birthday presents like that!” But she did not venture to say it out loud.
“Thinking again?” the Duchess asked, with another dig of her sharp little chin.
“I’ve a right to think,” said Alice sharply, for she was beginning to feel a little worried.
“Just about as much right,” said the Duchess, “as pigs have to fly; and the m—”

events.title: The Queen's Intervention and Game's End
detailed_summary: The Duchess abruptly falls silent mid-word ('moral'), and her arm linked with Alice's begins to shake.
Alice looks up to see the Queen standing before them, arms folded, looking furious.
In a weak voice, the Duchess attempts a polite greeting to the Queen.
The Queen ignores the greeting and shouts an ultimatum at the Duchess: remove herself or her head immediately.
The Duchess makes her choice and disappears instantly.
The Queen instructs Alice, who is too frightened to speak, to resume the croquet game.
Alice slowly follows the Queen back to the playing area.
The other players, who had been resting in the shade during the Queen's absence, scramble back to the game upon her return, warned by the Queen that any delay would result in their deaths.
Throughout the remainder of the game, the Queen continuously argues with players and shouts 'Off with his head!' or 'Off with her head!'
The soldiers, previously serving as croquet arches, have to leave their positions to escort the condemned players into custody.
Consequently, after about half an hour, no arches are left on the ground, and all players, apart from the King, the Queen, and Alice, have been arrested and sentenced to execution.
Finally, the Queen stops, completely out of breath.

events.text_segment:
But here, to Alice’s great surprise, the Duchess’s voice died away, even in the middle of her favourite word ‘moral,’ and the arm that was linked into hers began to tremble. Alice looked up, and there stood the Queen in front of them, with her arms folded, frowning like a thunderstorm.
“A fine day, your Majesty!” the Duchess began in a low, weak voice.
“Now, I give you fair warning,” shouted the Queen, stamping on the ground as she spoke; “either you or your head must be off, and that in about half no time! Take your choice!”
The Duchess took her choice, and was gone in a moment.
“Let’s go on with the game,” the Queen said to Alice; and Alice was too much frightened to say a word, but slowly followed her back to the croquet-ground.
The other guests had taken advantage of the Queen’s absence, and were resting in the shade: however, the moment they saw her, they hurried back to the game, the Queen merely remarking that a moment’s delay would cost them their lives.
All the time they were playing the Queen never left off quarrelling with the other players, and shouting “Off with his head!” or “Off with her head!” Those whom she sentenced were taken into custody by the soldiers, who of course had to leave off being arches to do this, so that by the end of half an hour or so there were no arches left, and all the players, except the King, the Queen, and Alice, were in custody and under sentence of execution.
Then the Queen left off, quite out of breath, and said to Alice, “Have you seen the Mock Turtle yet?”

events.title: Journey to the Mock Turtle
detailed_summary: Alice replies that she has not seen the Mock Turtle and doesn't even know what one is.
The Queen explains it's the creature from which Mock Turtle Soup is derived.
Alice reiterates she has never encountered or heard of such a creature.
The Queen invites Alice to come along, stating the Mock Turtle will recount his history to her.
As they depart, Alice hears the King quietly announce to the remaining group that they are all pardoned.
Alice silently expresses relief at this news, having been distressed by the number of executions ordered.
They quickly arrive at a spot where a Gryphon is fast asleep in the sun.
The Queen rouses the Gryphon, instructing it to take Alice to meet the Mock Turtle and hear his story.
The Queen explains she must return to oversee some executions and departs, leaving Alice with the Gryphon.
Alice feels uneasy about the Gryphon but judges staying with it to be as safe as pursuing the 'savage' Queen, so she waits.
The Gryphon sits up, rubs its eyes, watches the Queen until she is gone, and then chuckles.
It remarks, partly to itself and partly to Alice, 'What fun!'
When Alice inquires what is fun, the Gryphon clarifies it refers to the Queen.
The Gryphon assures Alice that the Queen's talk of executions is merely 'her fancy' and that nobody is ever actually executed, urging Alice to 'Come on!'
Alice follows slowly, reflecting internally that she has never been ordered around so much in her life.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “No,” said Alice.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Everybody says ‘come on!’ here,” thought Alice, as she went slowly after it: “I never was so ordered about in all my life, never!”

events.text_segment:
“No,” said Alice. “I don’t even know what a Mock Turtle is.”
“It’s the thing Mock Turtle Soup is made from,” said the Queen.
“I never saw one, or heard of one,” said Alice.
“Come on, then,” said the Queen, “and he shall tell you his history,”
As they walked off together, Alice heard the King say in a low voice, to the company generally, “You are all pardoned.” “Come, that’s a good thing!” she said to herself, for she had felt quite unhappy at the number of executions the Queen had ordered.
They very soon came upon a Gryphon, lying fast asleep in the sun. (If you don’t know what a Gryphon is, look at the picture.) “Up, lazy thing!” said the Queen, “and take this young lady to see the Mock Turtle, and to hear his history. I must go back and see after some executions I have ordered;” and she walked off, leaving Alice alone with the Gryphon. Alice did not quite like the look of the creature, but on the whole she thought it would be quite as safe to stay with it as to go after that savage Queen: so she waited.
The Gryphon sat up and rubbed its eyes: then it watched the Queen till she was out of sight: then it chuckled. “What fun!” said the Gryphon, half to itself, half to Alice.
“What is the fun?” said Alice.
“Why, she,” said the Gryphon. “It’s all her fancy, that: they never executes nobody, you know. Come on!”
“Everybody says ‘come on!’ here,” thought Alice, as she went slowly after it: “I never was so ordered about in all my life, never!”

“Come, THAT’S a good thing!” she said to herself, for she had felt quite unhappy at the number of executions the Queen had ordered.

They very soon came upon a Gryphon, lying fast asleep in the sun. (If you don’t know what a Gryphon is, look at the picture.) “Up, lazy thing!” said the Queen, “and take this young lady to see the Mock Turtle, and to hear his history. I must go back and see after some executions I have ordered;” and she walked off, leaving Alice alone with the Gryphon. Alice did not quite like the look of the creature, but on the whole she thought it would be quite as safe to stay with it as to go after that savage Queen: so she waited.

The Gryphon sat up and rubbed its eyes: then it watched the Queen till she was out of sight: then it chuckled. “What fun!” said the Gryphon, half to itself, half to Alice.

“What IS the fun?” said Alice.

“Why, SHE,” said the Gryphon. “It’s all her fancy, that: they never executes nobody, you know. Come on!”

“Everybody says ‘come on!’ here,” thought Alice, as she went slowly after it: “I never was so ordered about in all my life, never!”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“No,” said Alice. “I don’t think it would be at all nice to be that way.”

She was standing in the middle of a curious hall, with doors all round it, and she wondered how she was ever to get out again. Suddenly, she noticed a little three-legged table, all made of solid glass; there was nothing on it but a tiny golden key. Alice’s first thought was that it might belong to one of the doors of the hall; but, alas! either the locks were too large, or the key was too small, but at any rate it would not open any of them. However, on the second time round, she came upon a low curtain she had not noticed before, and behind it was a little door about fifteen inches high: she tried the little golden key in the lock, and to her great delight it fitted!

Alice opened the door and found that it led into a small passage, not much larger than a rat-hole: she knelt down and looked along the passage into the loveliest garden you ever saw. How she longed to get out of that dark hall, and wander about among those beds of bright flowers and those cool fountains, but she could not even get her head through the doorway; “and even if my head would go through,” thought poor Alice, “it would be of very little use without my shoulders. Oh, how I wish I could shut up like a telescope! I think I could, if I only knew how to begin.” For, you see, so many out-of-the-way things had happened lately, that Alice had begun to think that very few things indeed were really impossible.

events.title: The Mock Turtle's Tale of Education
detailed_summary: They soon see the Mock Turtle in the distance, appearing sad and lonely on a rock ledge, sighing audibly as they approach.
Alice feels deep sympathy and asks the Gryphon the cause of his sorrow.
The Gryphon dismisses the Mock Turtle's sadness as 'all his fancy,' insisting he has no real sorrow, and again says, 'Come on!'
They go up to the Mock Turtle, who observes them with large, tear-filled eyes but remains silent.
The Gryphon introduces Alice, explaining she wants to hear the Mock Turtle's history.
The Mock Turtle agrees in a somber tone, instructing both Alice and the Gryphon to sit down and not speak until he has finished.
They sit, and silence ensues for several minutes; Alice privately wonders how he can finish if he doesn't start, but waits patiently.
The Mock Turtle finally begins with a deep sigh, stating, 'Once... I was a real Turtle.'
This is followed by another long silence, punctuated only by the Gryphon's occasional 'Hjckrrh!' sound and the Mock Turtle's continuous, heavy sobbing.
Alice is tempted to leave after thanking him for the 'story' but senses there must be more to come, so she stays quiet.
The Mock Turtle resumes, calmer but still sobbing intermittently, describing attending school in the sea as a child.
He mentions the master was an old Turtle they called Tortoise.
Alice interrupts to ask why they called him Tortoise if he wasn't one.
The Mock Turtle irritably explains it was a pun ('because he taught us') and calls Alice 'very dull'.
The Gryphon adds that Alice should be ashamed for asking such a simple question, and they both fall silent, looking at Alice, who feels mortified.
Eventually, the Gryphon prompts the Mock Turtle to continue.
The Mock Turtle repeats that they went to school in the sea.
Alice interjects that she never said she didn't believe him.
The Mock Turtle insists she did.
The Gryphon silences Alice before she can respond further.
The Mock Turtle continues, claiming they received the finest education, attending school daily.
Alice mentions she also attended a day-school, suggesting he needn't be so proud.
The Mock Turtle anxiously asks if her school included 'extras'.
Alice confirms learning French and music.
The Mock Turtle then asks about 'washing'.
Alice replies indignantly that they certainly did not learn washing.
Relieved, the Mock Turtle declares Alice's school inferior because his school's bill listed 'French, music, and washing—extra'.
Alice points out that living at the bottom of the sea would make washing unnecessary.
The Mock Turtle sighs that he couldn't afford the extras and only took the standard course.
Alice inquires about the standard course.
The Mock Turtle lists the subjects: 'Reeling and Writhing' first, then Arithmetic branches named 'Ambition, Distraction, Uglification, and Derision'.
Alice ventures to ask about 'Uglification'.
The Gryphon reacts with surprise, asking if she truly hasn't heard of it and relating it to the concept of 'beautify,' concluding that if she doesn't know 'uglify,' she must be a simpleton.
Feeling discouraged, Alice turns back to the Mock Turtle and asks about other subjects.

The Mock Turtle enumerates more subjects using his flappers: 'Mystery' (ancient and modern) with 'Seaography,' then 'Drawling,' taught weekly by an old conger-eel master, which included 'Stretching' and 'Fainting in Coils'.
Alice asks what that class was like.
The Mock Turtle states he's too stiff to demonstrate and the Gryphon never learned it.
The Gryphon confirms, explaining he lacked time as he attended the Classics master, an old crab.
The Mock Turtle sighs that he never studied with the crab, who reportedly taught 'Laughing and Grief'.
The Gryphon confirms this, sighing as well, and both creatures cover their faces with their paws.
Alice quickly changes the subject, asking how many hours of lessons they had per day.
The Mock Turtle explains it was ten hours the first day, nine the second, and decreasing daily.
Alice finds this plan peculiar.
The Gryphon explains the term 'lessons' originates from this daily 'lessening' of hours.
This new idea intrigues Alice, and after some thought, she deduces the eleventh day must have been a holiday.
The Mock Turtle confirms it was.
Alice eagerly asks what happened on the twelfth day.
The Gryphon interrupts firmly, declaring that's enough discussion about lessons and instructs the Mock Turtle to talk about games instead.

events.text_segment:
They had not gone far before they saw the Mock Turtle in the distance, sitting sad and lonely on a little ledge of rock, and, as they came nearer, Alice could hear him sighing as if his heart would break. She pitied him deeply. “What is his sorrow?” she asked the Gryphon, and the Gryphon answered, very nearly in the same words as before, “It’s all his fancy, that: he hasn’t got no sorrow, you know. Come on!”
So they went up to the Mock Turtle, who looked at them with large eyes full of tears, but said nothing.
“This here young lady,” said the Gryphon, “she wants for to know your history, she do.”
“I’ll tell it her,” said the Mock Turtle in a deep, hollow tone: “sit down, both of you, and don’t speak a word till I’ve finished.”
So they sat down, and nobody spoke for some minutes. Alice thought to herself, “I don’t see how he can ever finish, if he doesn’t begin.” But she waited patiently.
“Once,” said the Mock Turtle at last, with a deep sigh, “I was a real Turtle.”
These words were followed by a very long silence, broken only by an occasional exclamation of “Hjckrrh!” from the Gryphon, and the constant heavy sobbing of the Mock Turtle. Alice was very nearly getting up and saying, “Thank you, sir, for your interesting story,” but she could not help thinking there must be more to come, so she sat still and said nothing.
“When we were little,” the Mock Turtle went on at last, more calmly, though still sobbing a little now and then, “we went to school in the sea. The master was an old Turtle—we used to call him Tortoise—”
“Why did you call him Tortoise, if he wasn’t one?” Alice asked.
“We called him Tortoise because he taught us,” said the Mock Turtle angrily: “really you are very dull!”
“You ought to be ashamed of yourself for asking such a simple question,” added the Gryphon; and then they both sat silent and looked at poor Alice, who felt ready to sink into the earth. At last the Gryphon said to the Mock Turtle, “Drive on, old fellow! Don’t be all day about it!” and he went on in these words:
“Yes, we went to school in the sea, though you mayn’t believe it—”
“I never said I didn’t!” interrupted Alice.
“You did,” said the Mock Turtle.
“Hold your tongue!” added the Gryphon, before Alice could speak again. The Mock Turtle went on.
“We had the best of educations—in fact, we went to school every day—”
“I’ve been to a day-school, too,” said Alice; “you needn’t be so proud as all that.”
“With extras?” asked the Mock Turtle a little anxiously.
“Yes,” said Alice, “we learned French and music.”
“And washing?” said the Mock Turtle.
“Certainly not!” said Alice indignantly.
“Ah! then yours wasn’t a really good school,” said the Mock Turtle in a tone of great relief. “Now at ours they had at the end of the bill, ‘French, music, and washing—extra.’”
“You couldn’t have wanted it much,” said Alice; “living at the bottom of the sea.”
“I couldn’t afford to learn it.” said the Mock Turtle with a sigh. “I only took the regular course.”
“What was that?” inquired Alice.
“Reeling and Writhing, of course, to begin with,” the Mock Turtle replied; “and then the different branches of Arithmetic—Ambition, Distraction, Uglification, and Derision.”
“I never heard of ‘Uglification,’” Alice ventured to say. “What is it?”
The Gryphon lifted up both its paws in surprise. “What! Never heard of uglifying!” it exclaimed. “You know what to beautify is, I suppose?”
“Yes,” said Alice doubtfully: “it means—to—make—anything—prettier.”
“Well, then,” the Gryphon went on, “if you don’t know what to uglify is, you are a simpleton.”
Alice did not feel encouraged to ask any more questions about it, so she turned to the Mock Turtle, and said “What else had you to learn?”
“Well, there was Mystery,” the Mock Turtle replied, counting off the subjects on his flappers, “—Mystery, ancient and modern, with Seaography: then Drawling—the Drawling-master was an old conger-eel, that used to come once a week: he taught us Drawling, Stretching, and Fainting in Coils.”
“What was that like?” said Alice.
“Well, I can’t show it you myself,” the Mock Turtle said: “I’m too stiff. And the Gryphon never learnt it.”
“Hadn’t time,” said the Gryphon: “I went to the Classics master, though. He was an old crab, he was.”
“I never went to him,” the Mock Turtle said with a sigh: “he taught Laughing and Grief, they used to say.”
“So he did, so he did,” said the Gryphon, sighing in his turn; and both creatures hid their faces in their paws.
“And how many hours a day did you do lessons?” said Alice, in a hurry to change the subject.
“Ten hours the first day,” said the Mock Turtle: “nine the next, and so on.”
“What a curious plan!” exclaimed Alice.
“That’s the reason they’re called lessons,” the Gryphon remarked: “because they lessen from day to day.”
This was quite a new idea to Alice, and she thought it over a little before she made her next remark. “Then the eleventh day must have been a holiday?”
“Of course it was,” said the Mock Turtle.
“And how did you manage on the twelfth?” Alice went on eagerly.
“That’s enough about lessons,” the Gryphon interrupted in a very decided tone: “tell her something about the games now.”

She pitied him deeply. "What is his sorrow?" she asked the Gryphon, and the Gryphon answered, very nearly in the same words as before, "It’s all his fancy, that: he hasn’t got no sorrow, you know. Come on!"

So they went up to the Mock Turtle, who looked at them with large eyes full of tears, but said nothing.

"This here young lady," said the Gryphon, "she wants for to know your history, she do."

"I’ll tell it her," said the Mock Turtle in a deep, hollow tone: "sit down, both of you, and don’t speak a word till I’ve finished."

So they sat down, and nobody spoke for some minutes. Alice thought to herself, "I don’t see how he can ever finish, if he doesn’t begin." But she waited patiently.

"Once," said the Mock Turtle at last, with a deep sigh, "I was a real Turtle."

These words were followed by a very long silence, broken only by an occasional exclamation of "Hjckrrh!" from the Gryphon, and the constant heavy sobbing of the Mock Turtle. Alice was very nearly getting up and saying, "Thank you, sir, for your interesting story," but she could not help thinking there must be more to come, so she sat still and said nothing.

"When we were little," the Mock Turtle went on at last, more calmly, though still sobbing a little now and then, "we went to school in the sea. The master was an old Turtle—we used to call him Tortoise—"

"Why did you call him Tortoise, if he wasn’t one?" Alice asked.

"We called him Tortoise because he taught us," said the Mock Turtle angrily: "really you are very dull!"

"You ought to be ashamed of yourself for asking such a simple question," added the Gryphon; and then they both sat silent and looked at poor Alice, who felt ready to sink into the earth. At last the Gryphon said to the Mock Turtle, "Drive on, old fellow! Don’t be all day about it!" and he went on in these words:

"Yes, we went to school in the sea, though you mayn’t believe it—"

"I never said I didn’t!" interrupted Alice.

"You did," said the Mock Turtle.

"Hold your tongue!" added the Gryphon, before Alice could speak again. The Mock Turtle went on.

"We had the best of educations—in fact, we went to school every day—"

"I’ve been to a day-school, too," said Alice; "you needn’t be so proud as all that."

"With extras?" asked the Mock Turtle a little anxiously.

"Yes," said Alice, "we learned French and music."

"And washing?" said the Mock Turtle.

"Certainly not!" said Alice indignantly.

"Ah! then yours wasn’t a really good school," said the Mock Turtle in a tone of great relief. "Now at ours they had at the end of the bill, ‘French, music, and washing—extra.’"

"You couldn’t have wanted it much," said Alice; "living at the bottom of the sea."

"I couldn’t afford to learn it." said the Mock Turtle with a sigh. "I only took the regular course."

"What was that?" inquired Alice.

"Reeling and Writhing, of course, to begin with," the Mock Turtle replied; "and then the different branches of Arithmetic—Ambition, Distraction, Uglification, and Derision."

"I never heard of ‘Uglification,’" Alice ventured to say. "What is it?"

The Gryphon lifted up both its paws in surprise. "What! Never heard of uglifying!" it exclaimed. "You know what to beautify is, I suppose?"

"Yes," said Alice doubtfully: "it means—to—make—anything—prettier."

"Well, then," the Gryphon went on, "if you don’t know what to uglify is, you are a simpleton."

Alice did not feel encouraged to ask any more questions about it, so she turned to the Mock Turtle, and said, "What else had you to learn?"

"Well, there was Mystery," the Mock Turtle replied, counting off the subjects on his flappers—"Mystery, ancient and modern, with Seaography: then Drawling—the Drawling-master was an old conger-eel, that used to come once a week: HE taught us Drawling, Stretching, and Fainting in Coils."

"What was that like?" said Alice.

"Well, I can’t show it you myself," the Mock Turtle said: "I’m too stiff. And the Gryphon never learnt it."

"Hadn’t time," said the Gryphon: "I went to the Classics master, though. He was an old crab, HE was."

"I never went to him," the Mock Turtle said with a sigh: "he taught Laughing and Grief, they used to say."

"So he did, so he did," said the Gryphon, sighing in his turn; and both creatures hid their faces in their paws.

"And how many hours a day did you do lessons?" said Alice, in a hurry to change the subject.

"Ten hours the first day," said the Mock Turtle: "nine the next, and so on."

"What a curious plan!" exclaimed Alice.

"That’s the reason they’re called lessons," the Gryphon remarked: "because they lessen from day to day."

This was quite a new idea to Alice, and she thought it over a little before she made her next remark. "Then the eleventh day must have been a holiday?"

"Of course it was," said the Mock Turtle.

"And how did you manage on the twelfth?" Alice went on eagerly.

"That’s enough about lessons," the Gryphon interrupted in a very decided tone: "tell her something about the games now."

"We called him Tortoise because he taught us," said the Mock Turtle angrily: "really you are very dull!"

"You ought to be ashamed of yourself for asking such a simple question," added the Gryphon; and then they both sat silent and looked at poor Alice, who felt ready to sink into the earth. At last the Gryphon said to the Mock Turtle, "Drive on, old fellow! Don’t be all day about it!" and he went on in these words:

"Yes, we went to school in the sea, though you mayn’t believe it—"

"I never said I didn’t!" interrupted Alice.

"You did," said the Mock Turtle.

"Hold your tongue!" added the Gryphon, before Alice could speak again. The Mock Turtle went on:

"We had the best of educations—in fact, we went to school every day—"

"I’ve been to a day-school, too," said Alice; "you needn’t be so proud as all that."

"With extras?" asked the Mock Turtle a little anxiously.

"Yes," said Alice, "we learned French and music."

"And washing?" said the Mock Turtle.

"Certainly not!" said Alice indignantly.

"Ah! then yours wasn’t a really good school," said the Mock Turtle in a tone of great relief. "Now at ours they had, at the end of the bill, ‘French, music, and washing—extra.’"

"You couldn’t have wanted it much," said Alice; "living at the bottom of the sea."

"I couldn’t afford to learn it," said the Mock Turtle with a sigh. "I only took the regular course."

"What was that?" inquired Alice.

"Reeling and Writhing, of course, to begin with," the Mock Turtle replied; "and then the different branches of Arithmetic—Ambition, Distraction, Uglification, and Derision."

"I never heard of ‘Uglification,’" Alice ventured to say. "What is it?"

The Gryphon lifted up both its paws in surprise. "What! Never heard of uglifying!" it exclaimed. "You know what to beautify is, I suppose?"

"Yes," said Alice doubtfully: "it means—to—make—anything—prettier."

"Well, then," the Gryphon went on, "if you don’t know what to uglify is, you are a simpleton."

Alice did not feel encouraged to ask any more questions about it, so she turned to the Mock Turtle, and said, "What else had you to learn?"

"Well, there was Mystery," the Mock Turtle replied, counting off the subjects on his flappers, "—Mystery, ancient and modern, with Seaography: then Drawling—the Drawling-master was an old conger-eel, that used to come once a week: HE taught us Drawling, Stretching, and Fainting in Coils."

"What was that like?" said Alice.

"Well, I can’t show it you myself," the Mock Turtle said: "I’m too stiff. And the Gryphon never learnt it."

"Hadn’t time," said the Gryphon: "I went to the Classics master, though. He was an old crab, HE was."

"I never went to him," the Mock Turtle said with a sigh: "he taught Laughing and Grief, they used to say."

"So he did, so he did," said the Gryphon, sighing in his turn; and both creatures hid their faces in their paws.

"And how many hours a day did you do lessons?" said Alice, in a hurry to change the subject.

"Ten hours the first day," said the Mock Turtle: "nine the next, and so on."

"What a curious plan!" exclaimed Alice.

"That’s the reason they’re called lessons," the Gryphon remarked: "because they lessen from day to day."

This was quite a new idea to Alice, and she thought it over a little before she made her next remark. "Then the eleventh day must have been a holiday?"

"Of course it was," said the Mock Turtle.

"And how did you manage on the twelfth?" Alice went on eagerly.

"That’s enough about lessons," the Gryphon interrupted in a very decided tone: "tell her something about the games now."

events.title: Mock Turtle's Sorrow and Introduction to the Lobster Quadrille
detailed_summary: The Mock Turtle expresses deep sadness, unable to speak through sobs.
The Gryphon physically assists the Mock Turtle to help him regain his voice, comparing the choking sound to having a bone in the throat.
With tears, the Mock Turtle resumes speaking to Alice.
He suggests Alice lacks understanding of undersea life, having likely never lived there or been introduced to a lobster.
Alice confirms her lack of undersea experience and, after almost mentioning tasting lobster, denies ever being introduced to one.
The Mock Turtle concludes that Alice cannot comprehend the delight of a Lobster Quadrille.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The Mock Turtle sighed deeply, and drew the back of one flapper across his eyes.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “—so you can have no idea what a delightful thing a Lobster Quadrille is!”

events.text_segment:
The Mock Turtle sighed deeply, and drew the back of one flapper across his eyes. He looked at Alice, and tried to speak, but for a minute or two sobs choked his voice. “Same as if he had a bone in his throat,” said the Gryphon: and it set to work shaking him and punching him in the back. At last the Mock Turtle recovered his voice, and, with tears running down his cheeks, he went on again:—
“You may not have lived much under the sea—” (“I haven’t,” said Alice)—“and perhaps you were never even introduced to a lobster—” (Alice began to say “I once tasted—” but checked herself hastily, and said “No, never”) “—so you can have no idea what a delightful thing a Lobster Quadrille is!”

events.title: Chaotic Description of the Lobster Quadrille
detailed_summary: Alice confirms she has no idea what the dance is like and asks for a description.
The Gryphon begins explaining the formation along the seashore.
The Mock Turtle interjects, specifying two lines composed of seals, turtles, salmon, etc., and mentions clearing jellyfish first.
The Gryphon interrupts to note that clearing jellyfish takes time.
The Mock Turtle continues, stating they advance twice.
The Gryphon excitedly adds that each dancer partners with a lobster.
The Mock Turtle confirms this and restates the steps: advance twice, set to partners.
The Gryphon adds the next steps: change lobsters and retire in the same order.
The Mock Turtle proceeds to describe throwing something.
The Gryphon shouts that it's the lobsters being thrown.
The Mock Turtle specifies throwing them far out to sea.
The Gryphon screams the next step: swimming after the lobsters.
The Mock Turtle excitedly cries out the next action: turning a somersault in the sea.
The Gryphon yells the subsequent step: changing lobsters again.
The Mock Turtle suddenly calms down, stating that returning to land concludes the first figure.
Both the Mock Turtle and Gryphon, previously jumping wildly, sit down sadly and look at Alice.
Alice timidly comments that it must be a very pretty dance.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “No, indeed,” said Alice.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “It must be a very pretty dance,” said Alice timidly.

events.text_segment:
“No, indeed,” said Alice. “What sort of a dance is it?”
“Why,” said the Gryphon, “you first form into a line along the sea-shore—”
“Two lines!” cried the Mock Turtle. “Seals, turtles, salmon, and so on; then, when you’ve cleared all the jelly-fish out of the way—”
“That generally takes some time,” interrupted the Gryphon.
“—you advance twice—”
“Each with a lobster as a partner!” cried the Gryphon.
“Of course,” the Mock Turtle said: “advance twice, set to partners—”
“—change lobsters, and retire in same order,” continued the Gryphon.
“Then, you know,” the Mock Turtle went on, “you throw the—”
“The lobsters!” shouted the Gryphon, with a bound into the air.
“—as far out to sea as you can—”
“Swim after them!” screamed the Gryphon.
“Turn a somersault in the sea!” cried the Mock Turtle, capering wildly about.
“Change lobsters again!” yelled the Gryphon at the top of its voice.
“Back to land again, and that’s all the first figure,” said the Mock Turtle, suddenly dropping his voice; and the two creatures, who had been jumping about like mad things all this time, sat down again very sadly and quietly, and looked at Alice.
“It must be a very pretty dance,” said Alice timidly.

events.title: Demonstration of the Quadrille and the Whiting's Song
detailed_summary: The Mock Turtle asks Alice if she'd like to see a bit of the dance.
Alice enthusiastically agrees.
The Mock Turtle suggests to the Gryphon they try the first figure, noting they can omit the lobsters, and asks who will sing.
The Gryphon designates the Mock Turtle to sing, admitting he has forgotten the words.
They commence a solemn dance around Alice, sometimes treading on her toes and using their forepaws to keep time.
The Mock Turtle sings a slow, sad song.
The song narrates a whiting urging a snail to hurry and join a dance because a porpoise is close behind.
The dance involves lobsters and turtles waiting on the shingle (beach).
The chorus repeatedly asks the snail to join the dance.
The whiting describes the delight of being taken up and thrown into the sea with the lobsters.
The snail refuses, saying it's too far and giving a wary look.
The snail reiterates its refusal to join.
The whiting argues that distance doesn't matter as there's another shore on the other side.
It reasons that being further from England means being closer to France.
The whiting encourages the snail not to be pale and to join the dance, repeating the chorus.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Would you like to see a little of it?” said the Mock Turtle.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Will you, won’t you, will you, won’t you, won’t you join the dance?”

events.text_segment:
“Would you like to see a little of it?” said the Mock Turtle.
“Very much indeed,” said Alice.
“Come, let’s try the first figure!” said the Mock Turtle to the Gryphon. “We can do without lobsters, you know. Which shall sing?”
“Oh, you sing,” said the Gryphon. “I’ve forgotten the words.”
So they began solemnly dancing round and round Alice, every now and then treading on her toes when they passed too close, and waving their forepaws to mark the time, while the Mock Turtle sang this, very slowly and sadly:—
“Will you walk a little faster?” said a whiting to a snail.
“There’s a porpoise close behind us, and he’s treading on my tail.
See how eagerly the lobsters and the turtles all advance!
They are waiting on the shingle—will you come and join the dance?
Will you, won’t you, will you, won’t you, will you join the dance?
Will you, won’t you, will you, won’t you, won’t you join the dance?

“You can really have no notion how delightful it will be
When they take us up and throw us, with the lobsters, out to sea!”
But the snail replied “Too far, too far!” and gave a look askance—
Said he thanked the whiting kindly, but he would not join the dance.
Would not, could not, would not, could not, would not join the dance.
Would not, could not, would not, could not, could not join the dance.

“What matters it how far we go?” his scaly friend replied.
“There is another shore, you know, upon the other side.
The further off from England the nearer is to France—
Then turn not pale, beloved snail, but come and join the dance.
Will you, won’t you, will you, won’t you, will you join the dance?
Will you, won’t you, will you, won’t you, won’t you join the dance?”

events.title: Discussion about Whitings, Wordplay, and Alice's Adventures
detailed_summary: Alice expresses relief that the dance is over, calling it interesting and saying she likes the song about the whiting.
The Mock Turtle asks Alice if she has seen whitings before.
Alice confirms, almost mentioning seeing them served at dinner ('dinn—'), but stops herself.
The Mock Turtle misunderstands 'Dinn' as a place but assumes Alice knows what whitings look like.
Alice thoughtfully replies that she thinks they have tails in their mouths and are covered in crumbs.
The Mock Turtle corrects her about the crumbs, stating they'd wash off in the sea, but confirms the tails-in-mouths detail.
Becoming sleepy, the Mock Turtle asks the Gryphon to explain the reason for the tails.
The Gryphon explains the whitings insisted on joining the lobsters' dance, got thrown out to sea, fell a long way, got their tails stuck fast in their mouths, and couldn't get them out.
Alice finds this interesting, noting she never knew so much about whitings.
The Gryphon offers more information, asking if Alice knows why it's called a 'whiting'.
Alice admits she never thought about it and asks why.
The Gryphon solemnly explains 'It does the boots and shoes,' a pun on shoe polish (whiting).
Alice is thoroughly confused by this statement.
The Gryphon asks what her shoes are shined with.
Alice examines her shoes and suggests they are shined with 'blacking'.
The Gryphon explains that undersea boots and shoes are 'done with a whiting'.
Alice curiously asks what undersea shoes are made of.
The Gryphon impatiently replies they are made of 'soles and eels', another pun.
Alice, still thinking of the song, says if she were the whiting, she'd tell the porpoise to stay away.
The Mock Turtle insists the porpoise was necessary, stating no wise fish travels without one.
Alice expresses surprise.
The Mock Turtle confirms, making a pun by saying if a fish mentioned a journey, he'd ask 'With what porpoise?'
Alice asks if he means 'purpose'.
The Mock Turtle replies, offended, that he means exactly what he said.
The Gryphon interjects, asking to hear Alice's adventures.

events.text_segment:
“Thank you, it’s a very interesting dance to watch,” said Alice, feeling very glad that it was over at last: “and I do so like that curious song about the whiting!”
“Oh, as to the whiting,” said the Mock Turtle, “they—you’ve seen them, of course?”
“Yes,” said Alice, “I’ve often seen them at dinn—” she checked herself hastily.
“I don’t know where Dinn may be,” said the Mock Turtle, “but if you’ve seen them so often, of course you know what they’re like.”
“I believe so,” Alice replied thoughtfully. “They have their tails in their mouths—and they’re all over crumbs.”
“You’re wrong about the crumbs,” said the Mock Turtle: “crumbs would all wash off in the sea. But they have their tails in their mouths; and the reason is—” here the Mock Turtle yawned and shut his eyes.—“Tell her about the reason and all that,” he said to the Gryphon.
“The reason is,” said the Gryphon, “that they would go with the lobsters to the dance. So they got thrown out to sea. So they had to fall a long way. So they got their tails fast in their mouths. So they couldn’t get them out again. That’s all.”
“Thank you,” said Alice, “it’s very interesting. I never knew so much about a whiting before.”
“I can tell you more than that, if you like,” said the Gryphon. “Do you know why it’s called a whiting?”
“I never thought about it,” said Alice. “Why?”
“It does the boots and shoes,” the Gryphon replied very solemnly.
Alice was thoroughly puzzled. “Does the boots and shoes!” she repeated in a wondering tone.
“Why, what are your shoes done with?” said the Gryphon. “I mean, what makes them so shiny?”
Alice looked down at them, and considered a little before she gave her answer. “They’re done with blacking, I believe.”
“Boots and shoes under the sea,” the Gryphon went on in a deep voice, “are done with a whiting. Now you know.”
“And what are they made of?” Alice asked in a tone of great curiosity.
“Soles and eels, of course,” the Gryphon replied rather impatiently: “any shrimp could have told you that.”
“If I’d been the whiting,” said Alice, whose thoughts were still running on the song, “I’d have said to the porpoise, ‘Keep back, please: we don’t want you with us!’”
“They were obliged to have him with them,” the Mock Turtle said: “no wise fish would go anywhere without a porpoise.”
“Wouldn’t it really?” said Alice in a tone of great surprise.
“Of course not,” said the Mock Turtle: “why, if a fish came to me, and told me he was going a journey, I should say ‘With what porpoise?’”
“Don’t you mean ‘purpose’?” said Alice.
“I mean what I say,” the Mock Turtle replied in an offended tone. And the Gryphon added “Come, let’s hear some of your adventures.”

events.title: Alice Recounts Adventures and Recites a Poem Incorrectly
detailed_summary: Alice timidly offers to share her adventures starting from that morning, explaining that recounting yesterday is pointless as she was a different person.
The Mock Turtle asks for an explanation of that.
The Gryphon impatiently interrupts, demanding the adventures first because explanations take too long.
Alice begins recounting her adventures from seeing the White Rabbit.
She is initially nervous due to the creatures' proximity and intense staring but gains confidence.
Her listeners remain quiet until she describes reciting 'You are old, Father William' incorrectly for the Caterpillar.
The Mock Turtle remarks that this is very curious.
The Gryphon agrees, stating it's as curious as can be.
The Mock Turtle thoughtfully repeats that the words came out differently and expresses a wish to hear Alice try reciting something now, asking the Gryphon to tell her to begin.
The Gryphon, seemingly having authority, instructs Alice to stand and recite ''Tis the voice of the sluggard.'
Alice privately reflects on how the creatures order her around like school lessons.
She stands up to recite, but her mind is preoccupied with the Lobster Quadrille.
The words come out strangely, beginning ''Tis the voice of the Lobster' who complains of being over-baked and needing to sugar his hair.
The recited poem continues nonsensically about the Lobster trimming his belt and buttons with his nose like a duck with its eyelids.

events.text_segment:
“I could tell you my adventures—beginning from this morning,” said Alice a little timidly: “but it’s no use going back to yesterday, because I was a different person then.”
“Explain all that,” said the Mock Turtle.
“No, no! The adventures first,” said the Gryphon in an impatient tone: “explanations take such a dreadful time.”
So Alice began telling them her adventures from the time when she first saw the White Rabbit. She was a little nervous about it just at first, the two creatures got so close to her, one on each side, and opened their eyes and mouths so very wide, but she gained courage as she went on. Her listeners were perfectly quiet till she got to the part about her repeating “You are old, Father William,” to the Caterpillar, and the words all coming different, and then the Mock Turtle drew a long breath, and said “That’s very curious.”
“It’s all about as curious as it can be,” said the Gryphon.
“It all came different!” the Mock Turtle repeated thoughtfully. “I should like to hear her try and repeat something now. Tell her to begin.” He looked at the Gryphon as if he thought it had some kind of authority over Alice.
“Stand up and repeat ‘’Tis the voice of the sluggard,’” said the Gryphon.
“How the creatures order one about, and make one repeat lessons!” thought Alice; “I might as well be at school at once.” However, she got up, and began to repeat it, but her head was so full of the Lobster Quadrille, that she hardly knew what she was saying, and the words came very queer indeed:—
“’Tis the voice of the Lobster; I heard him declare,
“You have baked me too brown, I must sugar my hair.”
As a duck with its eyelids, so he with his nose
Trims his belt and his buttons, and turns out his toes.”

“I daresay you haven’t had much practice,” said the Queen. “When I was your age, I always did it for half-an-hour a day. Why, sometimes I’ve believed as many as six impossible things before breakfast.”

“There’s no use trying,” she said: “one can’t believe impossible things.”

“I daresay you haven’t had much practice,” said the Queen. “When I was your age, I always did it for half-an-hour a day. Why, sometimes I’ve believed as many as six impossible things before breakfast.”

Alice laughed. “There’s no use trying,” she said: “one can’t believe impossible things.”

“I daresay you haven’t had much practice,” said the Queen. “When I was your age, I always did it for half-an-hour a day. Why, sometimes I’ve believed as many as six impossible things before breakfast.”

Alice thought to herself, “I wonder if I’ve been changed in the night? Let me think: was I the same when I got up this morning? I almost think I can remember feeling a little different. But if I’m not the same, the next question is, Who in the world am I? Ah, that’s the great puzzle!”

And she began thinking over all the children she knew that were of the same age as herself, to see if she could have been changed for any of them.

“I’m sure I’m not Ada,” she said, “for her hair goes in such long ringlets, and mine doesn’t go in ringlets at all; and I’m sure I can’t be Mabel, for I know all sorts of things, and she, oh! she knows such a very little! Besides, she’s she, and I’m I, and—oh dear, how puzzling it all is! I’ll try if I know all the things I used to know.”

events.title: Reactions to Recitation and Further Incorrect Poem
detailed_summary: The Gryphon observes that Alice's recitation differs from the version he knew as a child.
The Mock Turtle, having never heard it before, declares it sounds like 'uncommon nonsense'.
Alice remains silent, sitting down and covering her face, wondering if reality will ever return.
The Mock Turtle expresses a desire for an explanation.
The Gryphon hastily states that Alice cannot explain it and urges her to continue with the next verse.
The Mock Turtle persists, questioning how the lobster in the poem could turn its toes out using its nose.
Alice suggests it's the 'first position in dancing' but feels confused and wishes to change the topic.
The Gryphon impatiently repeats the instruction to proceed with the next verse, prompting her with the first line 'I passed by his garden.'
Feeling she cannot disobey but certain it will also come out wrong, Alice continues in a trembling voice.
She recites another altered verse about passing a garden and seeing an Owl and a Panther sharing a pie.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: That’s different from what I used to say when I was a child,” said the Gryphon.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: How the Owl and the Panther were sharing a pie—”

events.text_segment:
That’s different from what I used to say when I was a child,” said the Gryphon.
“Well, I never heard it before,” said the Mock Turtle; “but it sounds uncommon nonsense.”
Alice said nothing; she had sat down with her face in her hands, wondering if anything would ever happen in a natural way again.
“I should like to have it explained,” said the Mock Turtle.
“She can’t explain it,” said the Gryphon hastily. “Go on with the next verse.”
“But about his toes?” the Mock Turtle persisted. “How could he turn them out with his nose, you know?”
“It’s the first position in dancing.” Alice said; but was dreadfully puzzled by the whole thing, and longed to change the subject.
“Go on with the next verse,” the Gryphon repeated impatiently: “it begins ‘I passed by his garden.’”
Alice did not dare to disobey, though she felt sure it would all come wrong, and she went on in a trembling voice:—
“I passed by his garden, and marked, with one eye,
How the Owl and the Panther were sharing a pie—”

Alice said nothing; she sat down and covered her face with her hands, wondering if things would ever be quite the same again.

“I should like to have it explained,” said the Mock Turtle, looking at Alice with large, mournful eyes.

“She can’t explain it,” said the Gryphon hastily. “Go on with the next verse.”

“But how could a lobster turn its toes out with its nose?” persisted the Mock Turtle.

“It’s the first position in dancing, I think,” said Alice, though she felt more confused than ever, and wished they would change the subject.

“Go on with the next verse,” repeated the Gryphon impatiently. “It begins with ‘I passed by his garden.’”

Alice dared not disobey, though she was sure it would all come out wrong, and in a trembling voice she began:

“I passed by his garden, and marked, with a sigh,
An Owl and a Panther were sharing a pie:
The Panther took pie-crust, and gravy, and meat,
While the Owl had the dish as his share of the treat.”

---

**End of segment.**

This output closely follows the sequence of events and dialogue described in the summary, aligns with the opening line, and emulates the tone and style of the original text.

“Well, I never heard it before,” said Alice, “but it sounds uncommon nonsense.”

The Gryphon only smiled weakly, and said, “Go on with the next verse.”

“But about his toes?” the Mock Turtle persisted. “You haven’t explained all about his toes.”

“I was coming to that,” said the Gryphon. “The reason is—” but just then, the Mock Turtle interrupted with a deep sigh, and began to sob.

“Oh, please don’t be unhappy,” Alice said, feeling quite sorry for him. “I do so wish I could show you our school at home. We had the best teachers—”

“Ah! You may not have had lessons in Uglification,” the Gryphon remarked, “but we had the best masters for it. I could tell you all about it, if you like.”

“I should like it very much,” Alice replied politely.

“Very well,” said the Gryphon. “Let’s begin with the basics. Uglification, as you know, is the art of making things uglier. It’s a very important subject here.”

Alice listened, half amused and half bewildered, as the Gryphon launched into a detailed account of the curious lessons they had under the sea.

events.title: Mock Turtle Sings 'Turtle Soup' Before Abrupt Departure
detailed_summary: The Mock Turtle interrupts Alice's recitation again, questioning the point of repeating confusing material without explaining it.
He declares it the most confusing thing he has ever heard.
The Gryphon suggests Alice should stop reciting, and Alice is relieved to comply.
The Gryphon proposes either trying another figure of the Lobster Quadrille or having the Mock Turtle sing a song.
Alice eagerly requests a song, if the Mock Turtle is willing.
Her eagerness slightly offends the Gryphon, who comments on tastes and asks the Mock Turtle to sing 'Turtle Soup'.
The Mock Turtle sighs deeply and begins singing, his voice occasionally choked with sobs.
The song praises 'Beautiful Soup', describing it as rich, green, and waiting in a hot tureen.
It questions who wouldn't desire such dainties and celebrates 'Soup of the evening'.
The song continues, asking who cares for other dishes like fish or game when compared to Beautiful Soup.
It suggests giving up everything else for just a small amount of the soup.
The song repeats phrases and sounds emphasizing 'Beautiful Soup'.
The Gryphon calls for the chorus to be sung again.
Just as the Mock Turtle begins repeating the chorus, a distant cry announces 'The trial's beginning!'
The Gryphon exclaims 'Come on!', takes Alice by the hand, and rushes away without waiting for the song to finish.
As they run, Alice breathlessly asks what trial it is.
The Gryphon only replies 'Come on!' and runs faster.
The sad words of the Mock Turtle's song fade away on the breeze behind them.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “What is the use of repeating all that stuff,” the Mock Turtle interrupted, “if you don’t explain it as you go on?
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Beautiful, beautiful Soup!”

events.text_segment:
“What is the use of repeating all that stuff,” the Mock Turtle interrupted, “if you don’t explain it as you go on? It’s by far the most confusing thing I ever heard!”
“Yes, I think you’d better leave off,” said the Gryphon: and Alice was only too glad to do so.
“Shall we try another figure of the Lobster Quadrille?” the Gryphon went on. “Or would you like the Mock Turtle to sing you a song?”
“Oh, a song, please, if the Mock Turtle would be so kind,” Alice replied, so eagerly that the Gryphon said, in a rather offended tone, “Hm! No accounting for tastes! Sing her ‘Turtle Soup,’ will you, old fellow?”
The Mock Turtle sighed deeply, and began, in a voice sometimes choked with sobs, to sing this:—
“Beautiful Soup, so rich and green,
Waiting in a hot tureen!
Who for such dainties would not stoop?
Soup of the evening, beautiful Soup!
Soup of the evening, beautiful Soup!
    Beau—ootiful Soo—oop!
    Beau—ootiful Soo—oop!
Soo—oop of the e—e—evening,
    Beautiful, beautiful Soup!
“Beautiful Soup! Who cares for fish,
Game, or any other dish?
Who would not give all else for two p
ennyworth only of beautiful Soup?
Pennyworth only of beautiful Soup?
    Beau—ootiful Soo—oop!
    Beau—ootiful Soo—oop!
Soo—oop of the e—e—evening,
    Beautiful, beauti—FUL SOUP!”
“Chorus again!” cried the Gryphon, and the Mock Turtle had just begun to repeat it, when a cry of “The trial’s beginning!” was heard in the distance.
“Come on!” cried the Gryphon, and, taking Alice by the hand, it hurried off, without waiting for the end of the song.
“What trial is it?” Alice panted as she ran; but the Gryphon only answered “Come on!” and ran the faster, while more and more faintly came, carried on the breeze that followed them, the melancholy words:—
“Soo—oop of the e—e—evening,
Beautiful, beautiful Soup!”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“It’s by far the most confusing thing I ever heard!”

“I daresay you haven’t had much practice,” said the Mock Turtle. “When I was a little turtle, we went to school in the sea. The master was an old Turtle—we used to call him Tortoise—”

“Why did you call him Tortoise, if he wasn’t one?” Alice asked.

“We called him Tortoise because he taught us,” said the Mock Turtle angrily. “Really you are very dull!”

“You ought to be ashamed of yourself for asking such a simple question,” added the Gryphon; and then they both sat silent and looked at poor Alice, who felt ready to sink into the earth. At last the Gryphon said to the Mock Turtle, “Drive on, old fellow! Don’t be all day about it!” and he went on in these words:

“Yes, we went to school in the sea, though you mayn’t believe it—”

“I never said I didn’t!” interrupted Alice.

“You did,” said the Mock Turtle.

“Hold your tongue!” added the Gryphon, before Alice could speak again. The Mock Turtle went on:

“We had the best of educations—in fact, we went to school every day—”

“I’ve been to a day-school, too,” said Alice; “you needn’t be so proud as all that.”

“With extras?” asked the Mock Turtle a little anxiously.

“Yes,” said Alice, “we learned French and music.”

“And washing?” said the Mock Turtle.

“Certainly not!” said Alice indignantly.

“Ah! then yours wasn’t a really good school,” said the Mock Turtle in a tone of great relief. “Now at ours they had at the end of the bill, ‘French, music, and washing—extra.’”

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER XI. Who Stole the Tarts?

events.title: Arrival at the Trial and Initial Observations
detailed_summary: Alice enters the scene to find the King and Queen of Hearts presiding over a trial from their throne.
A diverse crowd of small animals, birds, and the entire deck of cards surrounds them.
The Knave of Hearts stands accused, bound in chains and guarded by soldiers.
The White Rabbit is present in the role of a court herald, equipped with a trumpet and a parchment scroll.
A table displaying a large dish of tarts captures Alice's attention, making her hungry and wish for the trial to conclude quickly so refreshments could be served.
Recognizing the improbability of immediate refreshments, Alice decides to observe the proceedings to occupy her time.
Although new to a real court of justice, Alice's reading allows her to identify various elements.
She correctly identifies the King as the judge, noting his large wig worn awkwardly beneath his crown.
Alice also identifies the jury-box and its twelve occupants, a mix of animals and birds, whom she proudly labels "jurors," reflecting on the advanced vocabulary for her age.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The King and Queen of Hearts were seated on their throne when they arrived, with a great crowd assembled about them—all sorts of little birds and beasts, as well as the whole pack of cards: the Knave was standing before them, in chains, with a soldier on each side to guard him; and near the King was the White Rabbit, with a trumpet in one hand, and a scroll of parchment in the other.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: However, “jury-men” would have done just as well.

events.text_segment:
The King and Queen of Hearts were seated on their throne when they arrived, with a great crowd assembled about them—all sorts of little birds and beasts, as well as the whole pack of cards: the Knave was standing before them, in chains, with a soldier on each side to guard him; and near the King was the White Rabbit, with a trumpet in one hand, and a scroll of parchment in the other. In the very middle of the court was a table, with a large dish of tarts upon it: they looked so good, that it made Alice quite hungry to look at them—“I wish they’d get the trial done,” she thought, “and hand round the refreshments!” But there seemed to be no chance of this, so she began looking at everything about her, to pass away the time.
Alice had never been in a court of justice before, but she had read about them in books, and she was quite pleased to find that she knew the name of nearly everything there. “That’s the judge,” she said to herself, “because of his great wig.”
The judge, by the way, was the King; and as he wore his crown over the wig, (look at the frontispiece if you want to see how he did it,) he did not look at all comfortable, and it was certainly not becoming.
“And that’s the jury-box,” thought Alice, “and those twelve creatures,” (she was obliged to say “creatures,” you see, because some of them were animals, and some were birds,) “I suppose they are the jurors.” She said this last word two or three times over to herself, being rather proud of it: for she thought, and rightly too, that very few little girls of her age knew the meaning of it at all. However, “jury-men” would have done just as well.

events.title: The Jury's Premature Actions
detailed_summary: Alice observes the twelve jurors busily writing on slates.
She curiously whispers to the Gryphon, asking what they could possibly be writing before the trial has even started.
The Gryphon explains in a whisper that the jurors are writing down their own names, fearing they might forget them before the trial concludes.
Alice begins to voice her indignation loudly, calling them "Stupid things!", but quickly falls silent as the White Rabbit demands order in the court.
Simultaneously, the King puts on his spectacles and scans the room, trying to identify the source of the interruption.
Alice can clearly see the jurors' slates, confirming they are indeed writing "stupid things!".
She notices one juror struggling to spell "stupid" and needing assistance from a neighbor.
Alice inwardly remarks on the chaotic state the jurors' notes will likely be in by the end of the trial.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The twelve jurors were all writing very busily on slates.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “A nice muddle their slates’ll be in before the trial’s over!” thought Alice.

events.text_segment:
The twelve jurors were all writing very busily on slates. “What are they doing?” Alice whispered to the Gryphon. “They can’t have anything to put down yet, before the trial’s begun.”
“They’re putting down their names,” the Gryphon whispered in reply, “for fear they should forget them before the end of the trial.”
“Stupid things!” Alice began in a loud, indignant voice, but she stopped hastily, for the White Rabbit cried out, “Silence in the court!” and the King put on his spectacles and looked anxiously round, to make out who was talking.
Alice could see, as well as if she were looking over their shoulders, that all the jurors were writing down “stupid things!” on their slates, and she could even make out that one of them didn’t know how to spell “stupid,” and that he had to ask his neighbour to tell him. “A nice muddle their slates’ll be in before the trial’s over!” thought Alice.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: MODEL_RESPONSE_BLOCKED

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: They were writing busily on slates, and Alice noticed that they were all writing down their own names, for fear they should forget them before the end of the trial. 'Stupid things!' Alice began to say aloud, but she checked herself hastily, for the White Rabbit was staring at her. The jury-box was full of all sorts of curious creatures: there were birds and beasts, and even a few insects. The King, who was presiding as judge, wore his crown over his wig, and looked rather uncomfortable. The Queen, meanwhile, was fidgeting impatiently, tapping her foot and muttering, 'Off with his head!' every now and then. Alice tried to pay attention to the proceedings, but it was difficult with so much commotion. The jurors kept dropping their pencils and picking them up again, and the courtroom was filled with a constant scratching noise from the slates.

events.title: Alice's Intervention and the Formal Accusation
detailed_summary: One juror possesses a pencil that emits a disruptive squeaking sound.
Finding the noise intolerable, Alice moves around the court until she is behind the juror.
She deftly seizes an opportunity to snatch the pencil away unnoticed.
The juror, identified as Bill the Lizard, is completely baffled by the pencil's sudden disappearance.
After a futile search, Bill resorts to writing with his finger for the remainder of the day, which proves ineffective as it leaves no marks on the slate.
The King then instructs the Herald (White Rabbit) to formally read the charges.
Following the King's command, the White Rabbit produces three blasts from his trumpet.
He then unrolls the parchment scroll and recites the accusation: a nursery rhyme detailing how the Knave of Hearts allegedly stole the Queen's tarts.
Immediately upon hearing the charges, the King instructs the jury to deliberate and reach their verdict.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: One of the jurors had a pencil that squeaked.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Consider your verdict,” the King said to the jury.

events.text_segment:
One of the jurors had a pencil that squeaked. This of course, Alice could not stand, and she went round the court and got behind him, and very soon found an opportunity of taking it away. She did it so quickly that the poor little juror (it was Bill, the Lizard) could not make out at all what had become of it; so, after hunting all about for it, he was obliged to write with one finger for the rest of the day; and this was of very little use, as it left no mark on the slate.
“Herald, read the accusation!” said the King.
On this the White Rabbit blew three blasts on the trumpet, and then unrolled the parchment scroll, and read as follows:—
“The Queen of Hearts, she made some tarts,
    All on a summer day:
The Knave of Hearts, he stole those tarts,
    And took them quite away!”
“Consider your verdict,” the King said to the jury.

events.title: The Hatter's Arrival and Confusing Testimony
detailed_summary: The White Rabbit quickly intervenes, telling the King it's too early for a verdict as much evidence is yet to be presented.
The King concedes and requests the first witness.
The White Rabbit blows his trumpet again and summons the "First witness!"
The Hatter enters, still holding his teacup and a piece of bread-and-butter.
He apologizes to the King for bringing his tea things, explaining he was summoned before finishing.
The King retorts that he should have finished and inquires when he started his tea.
The Hatter looks towards the March Hare, who has entered with the Dormouse, and guesses the date was March 14th.
The March Hare corrects him, stating it was the 15th; the Dormouse adds it was the 16th.
The King instructs the jury to write down all three dates, which they do eagerly, before attempting to convert the dates into monetary values.
The King then orders the Hatter to remove his hat.
The Hatter replies that the hat is not his.
The King immediately concludes the hat must be "Stolen!" and directs the jury to record this, which they do instantly.
The Hatter clarifies that he is a hatter by trade and keeps hats for sale, possessing none of his own.
At this point, the Queen puts on her spectacles and begins to stare intently at the Hatter, making him turn pale and fidget nervously.
The King demands the Hatter give his evidence, warning him not to be nervous under threat of immediate execution.
This threat fails to calm the Hatter; he shifts anxiously from foot to foot, glancing worriedly at the Queen, and in his disarray, bites a chunk out of his teacup instead of his bread-and-butter.
Simultaneously, Alice becomes aware of a peculiar physical sensation and realizes she has begun to grow taller again; considering leaving, she ultimately decides to stay as long as space permits.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Not yet, not yet!” the Rabbit hastily interrupted.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Just at this moment Alice felt a very curious sensation, which puzzled her a good deal until she made out what it was: she was beginning to grow larger again, and she thought at first she would get up and leave the court; but on second thoughts she decided to remain where she was as long as there was room for her.

events.text_segment:
“Not yet, not yet!” the Rabbit hastily interrupted. “There’s a great deal to come before that!”
“Call the first witness,” said the King; and the White Rabbit blew three blasts on the trumpet, and called out, “First witness!”
The first witness was the Hatter. He came in with a teacup in one hand and a piece of bread-and-butter in the other. “I beg pardon, your Majesty,” he began, “for bringing these in: but I hadn’t quite finished my tea when I was sent for.”
“You ought to have finished,” said the King. “When did you begin?”
The Hatter looked at the March Hare, who had followed him into the court, arm-in-arm with the Dormouse. “Fourteenth of March, I think it was,” he said.
“Fifteenth,” said the March Hare.
“Sixteenth,” added the Dormouse.
“Write that down,” the King said to the jury, and the jury eagerly wrote down all three dates on their slates, and then added them up, and reduced the answer to shillings and pence.
“Take off your hat,” the King said to the Hatter.
“It isn’t mine,” said the Hatter.
“Stolen!” the King exclaimed, turning to the jury, who instantly made a memorandum of the fact.
“I keep them to sell,” the Hatter added as an explanation; “I’ve none of my own. I’m a hatter.”
Here the Queen put on her spectacles, and began staring at the Hatter, who turned pale and fidgeted.
“Give your evidence,” said the King; “and don’t be nervous, or I’ll have you executed on the spot.”
This did not seem to encourage the witness at all: he kept shifting from one foot to the other, looking uneasily at the Queen, and in his confusion he bit a large piece out of his teacup instead of the bread-and-butter.
Just at this moment Alice felt a very curious sensation, which puzzled her a good deal until she made out what it was: she was beginning to grow larger again, and she thought at first she would get up and leave the court; but on second thoughts she decided to remain where she was as long as there was room for her.

“Fifteenth,” said the March Hare.

“Sixteenth,” added the Dormouse.
